editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TRYAL OF Spencer Cowper, Esq Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens, and William Rogers, Gent.
Upon an Indictment for the Murther of Mrs SARAH STOUT, a Quaker.
Before Mr Baron Hatsell, at Hertford Assizes, Iuly 18. 1699.
Of which they were Acquitted.
With the Opinions of the Eminent Physicians and Chyrurgeons on both sides, concerning Drowned Bodies, delivered in the Tryal.
AND
The several Letters produced in Court.
LONDON, Printed for Isaac Cleave in Chancery-lane, Matt. Wotton in Fleetstreet, and Iohn Bullord. 1699.
I Do appoint Isaac Cleave, Matthew Wotton, and Iohn Bullord, to Print the Tryal of Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens, and William Rogers: And that no other person presume to Print the same.

div.head: The Tryal of Spencer Cowper, Esq &c.
div.p: Proclamation was made for all persons concerned to attend

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: YOu good men that are empanell'd to enquire, &c. answer to your names, and save your Fines.

div.p: Then Ellis Stephens, William Rogers and Iohn Marson being upon Bail, Proclamation was made for them to attend, which they accordingly did, and Mr Cowper was brought into Court by the Under-Sheriff.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Spencer Cowper hold up thy hand. (which he did.) Iohn Marson hold up thy hand. (which he did.) Ellis Stevens hold up thy hand. (which he did.) William Rogers hold up thy hand. (which he did.)

You stand Indicted by the names of Spencer Cowper, late of the Parish of St Iohns, in the Town of Hertford, in the County of Hertford, Esq Iohn Marson, late of the Parish aforesaid, in the County aforesaid, Gent. Ellis Stevens, late of the Parish aforesaid, in the County aforesaid, Gent. and VVilliam Rogers, late of the Parish aforesaid, in the County aforesaid, Gent. For that you not having God before your eyes, but being moved and seduced by the instigation of the Devil, on the thirteenth day of March, in the eleventh year of the Reign of his present Majesty, by force and arms, &c. at the Parish aforesaid, in the County aforesaid, in and upon one Sarah Stout Spinster, in the peace of God and our Soveraign Lord the King, then and there being, violently, feloniously, voluntarily, and of your malice aforethought, did make an assault; and that you the aforesaid Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens, and VVilliam Rogers, a certain Rope of no value. about the neck of the said Sarah then and there feloniously, voluntarily, and of your malice aforethought, did put, place▪ fix and bind, and the neck and throat of the said Sarah, then and there with the hands of you the said Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens and William Rogers, feloniously, voluntarily, and of your malice aforethought, did hold, squeeze, and gripe: And that you the said Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens, and VVilliam Rogers, with the aforesaid Rope, by you the said Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens and VVilliam Rogers, then as aforesaid about the neck of the aforesaid Sarah Stout put, placed, fixed, bound, and by the squeezing and griping of the neck and throat of the said Sarah with the hands of you the said Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens and William Rogers as aforesaid, the said Sarah Stout then and there, by force and arms, &c. feloniously, voluntarily, and of your malice aforethought, did choak and strangle; by reason of which choaking and strangling of her the said Sarah Stout, by you the aforesaid Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens and VVilliam Rogers, with the said Rope about the neck of the said Sarah Stout as aforesaid, placed, fixed and bound, and by the squeezing and griping of the neck and throat of the said Sarah with the hands of you the said Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens and VVilliam Rogers, as aforesaid, the said Sarah then and there instantly dyed: And so you the said Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens and VVilliam Rogers, the said Sarah Stout, on the thirteenth day of March, in the year aforesaid, in the Parish aforesaid, in the County aforesaid, in manner and form aforesaid, feloniously, voluntarily, and of your malice aforethought, did kill and murder; and the said Sarah Stout, as aforesaid, by you the said Spencer Cowper, Iohn Marson, Ellis Stevens and VVilliam Rogers, feloniously, voluntarily, and out of your malice aforethought, choaked and strangled, into a certain River there, being called the Priory River, then secretly and maliciously did put and cast, to conceal and hide the said Sarah Stout so murdered, against the peace of our Soveraign Lord the King, his Crown and Dignity, &c. How sayst thou Spencer Cowper, art thou Guilty of the Felony and Murder whereof thou standst Indicted, or Not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr. Culprit.
sp.p: How wilt thou be tried?

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: By God and my Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: God send you a good deliverance.

div.p: Then the other three pleaded likewise Not Guilty, and put themselves upon their Country in manner aforesaid.
Then Proclamation was made for Information.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: You the Prisoners at the •… ar▪ These men that you shall hear call'd, and personally appear, are to pass between our Soveraign Lord the King and you, upon Trial of your several lives and deaths: Therefore if you will challenge 'em, or any of 'em, your time to speak is as they come to the Book to be Sworn, before they be Sworn.

div.p: Then the pannel was called over.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Do you design to ioyn in your Challenges, or to Challenge separately?

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: If we should Challenge separately, there must be so many separate Tryals, and therefore to prevent the trouble of the Court, I am willing there should be but one Challenge for all.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Do you all agree to that?

sp.speaker: Prisoners.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

div.p: Then after some Challenges, as well on the part of the King as of the Prisoners, there not being a full Jury of the principal Pannel:

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: IF your Lordship please, the Pannel is now gone through, I desire they may shew some legal Cause for their Challenges.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: I conceive we that are retain'd for the King are not bound to shew any Cause, or the Cause is sufficient if we say they are not Good for the King, and that is allow'd to be a good Cause of Challenge, for what other Cause can we shew in this Case. You are not to shew your Cause, you Challenge peremptorily, so in this Case the King does.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord, I stand at the Bar with some disadvantage, to encounter a Gentleman that hath no Concernment; but however, I do take it for Law, that there must be a Cause shew'd, and that Cause must be a legal one, and what that Cause is they must certainly make out. I do think it ought to appear that there is some relation, or some notorious affection or friendship, or something of that sort, or otherwise it is not a legal Cause of Challenge; and if there seem to be any difficulty in this particular, I hope your Lordship will assign me Councel to argue it with the Kings Councel.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Mr Cowper, you are not under such disadvantage as men usually are that stand where you now do. You have been educated in the study of the Law, and understand it very well, I have several times seen how you have manag'd your Clients Causes to their advantage. As for this matter of Challenge, Mr Iones, I think you should shew your Cause of Challenge, tho the Law allows the Prisoner the liberty to Challenge 20 peremptorily.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: I don't know, in all my practice of this nature, that it was ever put upon the King to shew Cause, and I believe some of the Kings Councel will say they have not known it done.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: In my I▪. Ch. Justice Hales's Pleas of the Crown, p. 259. it is expressly so▪ and in the Statute of 33 E. 1. 'tis said the King shall not Challenge without Cause, and that must be legal▪

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Call Daniel Clarke.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Mr Iones, if you can say any Jury-man hath said any thing concerning this Cause, and given his Verdict by way of discourse, or shew'd his affection one way or other, that would be good Cause of Challenge.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: My Lord, then we should keep you here while to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: If there hath been any great friendship between any Jury-man and the party, it will look ill if he be insisted upon.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord, I don't insist upon it, but I profess I know of no Friendship, only that Mr Clarke in Elections hath taken our Interest in Town; I know I have a just Cause, and I am ready to be tryed before your Lordship▪ and any fair Jury of the County; therefore I do not insist upon it.

div.p: Then the Jury sworn was as followeth:

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly move that I may have Pen, Ink and Paper.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Ay, by all means.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Hold up your hand. (which he did) And so of the rest; You of the Jury look upon the Prisoners, and hearken to their charge. They stand Indicted by the names of, &c. (Prout in the Indictment (mutatis mutandis:)

sp.speaker: Iury.
sp.p: My Lord, we desire we may have Pen, Ink and Paper.

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Assize.
sp.p: There are three of the Jury desire Pen, Ink and Paper.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Let as many have it as will.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones
sp.p: May it please your Lordship, and you Gentlemen that are sworn, I am of Councel for the King in this Cause, and it is▪ upon an Indictment by which the Gentlemen at the Bar stand accus'd for one of the foulest and most wicked Crimes almost that any age can remember; I believe in your County you never knew a fact of this nature: For here is a young Gentlewoman of this County murder'd and strangled in the night time. The thing was done in the dark, therefore the Evidence cannot be so plain as otherwise might be.

After she was strangled and murder'd, she was carried and thrown into a River to stifle the fact, and to make it suppos'd that she had murder'd herself; that it was ineded, if it prove otherwise, a double Murder, and a Murder accompanied with all the Circumstances of Wickedness and Villany that I remember in all my Practice, or ever read of.

This Fact, as it was committed in the night time, so it was carried very secret, and it is very well we have had so much light as we have to give so much satisfaction: For we have here in a manner two Tryals, one to acquit the party that is dead, and to satisfie the world, and vindicate her reputation that she did not murder herself▪ but was murder'd by other hands. For my part, I shall never as Councel in the case of Blood aggravate; I will not improve or enlarge the Evidence at all, it shall be only my business to set the Fact as it is, and to give the Evidence, and state it as it stands here in my Instructions.

My Lord, for that purpose, to lead to the Fact, it will be necessary to inform you that upon Monday the 13th of March, the first day of the last Assizes here, Mr Cowper, one of the Gentlemen at the Bar, came to this Town, and lighted at Mr Barefoot's house, and staid there some time, I suppose, to dry himself, the weather beingdirty, but sent his Horse to Mrs Stout's, the Mother of this Gentlewoman. Some time after he came thither himself, and din'd there, and staid till 4 in the afternoon; at 4 when he went away, he told them he would come and lodge there that night, and Sup.

According to his word he came there, and had the Supper he desired, after Supper Mrs Stout the young Gentlewoman and he sat together till near 11 a clock. At 11 a clock there was orders given to warm his Bed, openly to warm his Bed in his hearing. The Maid of the house, Gentlemen, upon this went up stairs to warm his Bed, expecting the Gentleman would have come up and followed her before she had done, but it seems while she was warming of the Bed she heard the door clap together, and the nature of that door is such, that it makes a great noise at the clapping of it to, that any body in the House may be sensible of any ones going out. The Maid upon this was concern'd, and wonder'd at the meaning of it, he promising to lye there that night; she came down, but there was neither Mr Cowper nor Mrs Stout, so that we suppose, and for all that we can find and learn, they must go out together. After their going out, the Maid and Mother came into the Room, and the young Gentlewoman not returning, nor Mr Cowper, they sat up all night in the house, expecting what time the young Gentlewoman would return. The next morning after they had sat up all night, the first news of this Lady was, that she lay floating and swimming in water by the Mill-Damm. Upon that there was several persons call'd; for it was a surprize how this should come to pass. There she lay floating with her Petticoats and Apron, but her Night-rail and Morning-gown were off, and one of them not found till some time after; and the Maid will give you an account how it came to be found.

This made a great noise in the Country; for it was very extraordinary, it hapning that from the time the Maid left Mr Cowper and this young Gentlewoman together▪ she was not seen or heard of till next morning, when she was found in this condition, with her Eyes broad open, floating upon the water.

When her Body came to be view'd it was very much wonder'd at: For in the first place it is contrary to nature, that any persons that drown themselves, should float upon the water. We have sufficient Evidence that it is a thing that never was, if persons come alive into the water then they sink, if dead then they swim, that made some more curious to look into this matter. At first it was thought that such an accident might happen, though they could not imagin any cause for this woman to do so, who had so great Prosperity, had so good an Estate, and had no occasion to do an action upon her self so wicked and so barbarous, nor cannot learn what reason she had to induce her to such a thing. Upon view of the Body it did appear there had been violence used to the woman, there was a crease round her Neck, she was bruised about her Ear, so that it did seem as if she had been strangled either by Hands or a Rope.

Gentlemen, upon the examination of this matter, it was wondred how this matter came about, it was dark and blind. The Coroner at that time, nor these people had no Evidence given, but the ordinary Evidence, and it pass'd in a day. We must call our Witnesses to this Fact, that of necessity you must conclude she was strangled, and did not drown her self; If we give you as strong a proof as can be upon the nature of the Fact that she was strangled, then the 2d matter under your enquiry will be, to know who, or what persons should be the men that did the Fact. I told you before it was, as all wicked actions are, a matter of darkness, and done in secret, to be kept as much from the knowledge of men as was possible.
Truly, Gentlemen, as to the persons at the Bar, the Evidence of the Fact will be •… ery▪ short, and will be to this purpose.

Mr Cowper was the last man unfortunately in her Company, I could wish he had not been so with all my heart, 'tis a very unfortunate thing, that his name should upon this occasion be brought upon the Stage; but then, my Lord, it was a strange thing; here happens to be three Gentlemen, Mr Marson, Mr Rogers, and Mr Stevens, as to these 3 men my, Lord, I don't hear of any business they had here, unless it was to do this matter, to serve some Interest or Friend, that sent them upon this message, for my Lord, they came to Town, (and in things of this nature, 'tis well we have this Evidence, but if we had not been streightned in time it would have brought out more, these things come out slowly) these persons, Mr Stevens, Mr Rogers, and Mr Marson came to Town here on the 13th of March last, the Assize day: My Lord, when they came to Town, they came to an House, and took Lodgings at one Gurreys, they took a Bed for two and went out of their Lodging, having taken a room with a large Bed in it, and afterwards they went to the Glove and Dolphin, and then about 8 a Clock one Marson came to them there; in what company they came, your Lordship and the Jury will know by and by, they staid there, my Lord, at the Glove from 8 a Clock to 11, as they say. At 11 these three Gentlemen came all in to their Lodging together to this Gurreys; my Lord, when they came in, it was very observable amongst them, unless there had been a sort of fate in it: •… st, That they should happen to be in the condition they were in, and 2dly, fall upon the discourse they did at that time; for my Lord, they call'd for Fire, and the Fire was made them, and while the people of the House were going about, they observ'd and heard these Gentlemen talk of Mrs Sarah Stout, that happened to be their discourse, one said to the other, Marson, she was an old Sweet-heart of yours: Ay, saith he, but she cast me off, but I reckon by this time a Friend of mine has done her business: another piece of discourse was, I believe a Friend of mine is even with her by this time. They had a bundle of Linnen with them, but what it was is not known, and one takes the bundle and throws it upon the Bed, well, saith he, her business is done, Mrs Sarah Stout's courting days are over, and they sent for Wine, my Lord; so after they had drank of the Wine they talk'd of it, and one pulled out a great deal of Money, saith one to another, what Money have you spent to day? Saith the other, thou hast had 40 or 50 l. for thy share: Saith the other, I will spend all the money I have, for joy the business is done.

My Lord, this discourse hapned to be among them, which made the People of the House consider and bethink themselves, when the next day they heard of this Mrs Stout's being found in the water, this made them recollect and call to mind all these discourses.

My Lord, after these Gentlemen had staid there all night, next morning truly it was observ'd (and I suppose some account will be given of it) that Mr Cowper and they did meet together, and had several discourses, and that very day went out of Town, and I think as soon as they came to Hooddesdon, made it all their discourse and business to talk of Mrs Stout.

My Lord, we will call our Witnesses, and prove all these Facts that I have opened to your Lordship, and then I hope they will be put to give you some account how all these matters came about. Call Sarah Walker (who was sworn)

sp.speaker: Mr Iones,
sp.p: Mrs Walker pray give an account to my Lord and the Jury, of Mr Cowper's coming to your house the 13th of March, and what was done from his coming there at night to his going out.

sp.speaker: Sarah Walker.
sp.p:
May it please you, my Lord, on Friday before the last Assizes, Mr Cowper's Wife sent a Letter to Mistress Stout, that she might expect Mr Cowper at the Assize time, and therefore we expected Mr Cowper at that time, and accordingly provided; and as he came in with the Judges, she ask'd him if he would alight, he said no, by reason I come in later than usual, I will go into the Town and show my self, but he would send his Horse presently; she ask'd him, how long it would be before he would come, because they would stay for him; he said, he could not tell, but he would send her word, and she thought he had forgot, and sent me down to know, whether he would please to come: he said, he had business, and he could not come just then, but he came in less than a quarter of an hour after, and din▪d there, and he went away at 4 a Clock, and then my Mistress askt him, if he would lye there, and he answer'd yes, and he came at night about 9 a Clock, and he sat talking about half an hour, and then call'd for Pen, Ink and Paper, for that, as he said, he was to write to his Wife, which was brought him, and he wrote a Letter, and then my Mistress went and askt him, what he would have for Supper, he said Milk, by reason he had made a good Dinner; and I got him his Supper and he eat it, after she called me
in again, and they were talking together, and then she bid me make a Fire in this Chamber, and when I had done •… o I came and told him of it, and he look'd at me, and made me no answer; then •… he bid me warm the Bed, which accordingly I went up to do as the Clock struck 11, and in about a quarter of an hour, I heard the door, shut, and I thought he was gone to carry the Letter, and staid about a quarter of an hour longer and came down, and he was gone and she, and Mrs Stout the Mother, ask'd me the reason why he went out when I was warming his Bed, and she askt me for my Mistress, and I told her, I left her with Mr Cowper, and I never saw her after that, nor did Mr Cowper return to the house.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How long did you sit up?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: All night.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: What time next morning did you see her?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: About 7 a clock.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: In the Water, or out?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Out of the Water.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray will you recollect a little, and be very particular as to the time when I went out at night.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Sir, it was a quarter after 11 by our Clock, the difference between the Town Clock and ours was half an hour.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: But you say by your Clock it was a quarter after 11.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray▪ what account did you give as to the time to the Coroners Inquest?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I said then it was 11, or a quarter after 11, when I heard the door shut.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray was Mistress Stout present with the Coroners Inquest when you gave that account?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes, she was,

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray what account did you give as to the time before my L. C. J. Holt?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I gave the account that it was 11, or a quarter of an hour after.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: In her Depositions there is half an hours difference, for then she said it was half an hour after 10.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Which Clock was earliest, yours or the Town Clock?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Ours was half an hour faster than theirs.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: So then it wanted a quarter of 11 by the Town Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: How came you to know this?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: By reason that Dinner was drest at the Cooks, and it was order'd to be ready by 2 a clock, and it was ready at 2 a clock by the Town clock, and half an hour after 2 by ours.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: When you came down and mist your Mistress, did you enquire after her all that night?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No Sir, I did not go out of the doors; I thought you were with her, and so I thought she would come to no harm.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Here is a whole night she gives no account of. Pray Mistress why did not you go after her?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: My Mistress would not let me.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Why would she not let you?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I said I would see for her: No, saith she, by reason if you go and see for her, and do not find her, it will make an alarm over the Town, and there may be no occasion.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did your Mistress use to stay out all night?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Have not you said so?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I never said so in my life▪

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray Mrs Walker did you never take notice that your Mistress was under Melancholy?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I don't say but she was melancholy; she was ill for some time, and I imputed it to her illness, and I know no other cause.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Have you not often told people that your Aeistress was a melancholy person, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I have said she hath been ill, and that made her melancholy.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: I will ask you this question, Pray did you ever purchase any Poyson, more or less, within these twelvemonths?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I did so, and can tell what it was for.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: By whose order?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: By my own order.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you buy Poyson but once, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I believe I might buy twice.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Of Mr Ludman.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Both times there?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Of him?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No, of the young man.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you ever buy any Poison at Luto •… ?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you ever buy any by your Mistresses order, or of one Mrs Crooke, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No, I never did.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray at what time was it you bought this Poyson you speak of?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I can't remember.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray recollect your self.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: It was within this half year to be sure.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: What was the name of the Poyson you askt for?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I askt for White Mercury.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p:
She saith, I past by her Mistresses house, and went directly to Mr Banefoo •…
's, pray did not you come to Mr Barefoot's after me?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: Pray did you give the same account before the Coroner, when this matter was enquir'd into, that you have now done?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes I did as near as I can tell.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you give this account in substance?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bar.
sp.p: Hatsell. Mr Cowper, I suppose you don't mean in relation to the Poyson.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord I mean in relation to so much of the evidence which she now gives, and particularly respects me. For what end or purpose did you buy it?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I bought it to poyson a Dog.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Why should you poyson the Dog?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: It was a Dog that us'd to haunt our House that did us a great deal of mischief, but that did not do, so I bought it a 2d time.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Who gave it to the Dog?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: 'Twas another maid did give it the Dog.

sp.speaker: MrCowper.
sp.p: Why did you then swear it was given the Dog.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Sir I saw it given.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did your Mistress know of it?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes she did know of it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: How did you give it?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: In warm Milk.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: How did the Milk look?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: It did not look discolour'd in the least.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.p: Hatsell You said just now your Mistress was ill, and that made her melancholy, what illness was it?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: My Lord, she had a great pain in her head.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.p: Hatsell. How long had she been troubled with it?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Ever since last May was twelvemonths was the beginning of it.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you ever find her in the least inclin'd to do herself a mischief?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No I never did.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: You bought Poyson twice, did you give all the Poyson you bought to the Dog?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: The first and the last?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes the whole.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: How much did you buy?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I am not certain how much I bought.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray what mischief did it do the Dog?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I cannot tell, he may be alive till now for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: What mischief did the Dog do?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: A great deal, he threw down several things and broke them.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did Mr Cowper upon your Oath, hear Mistress Stout give you order to make his Fire and warm his Bed?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: He knows best, whether he heard it or no; but he sat by her when she spake it.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did she speak it so as he might hear?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes she did, for he was nearer than I.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: And did not he contradict it?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was it the old or young woman, that gave you the order?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: The young woman

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray did the Dog lap it, or did you poure it down his Throat, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No he lapt it upon my Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did Mr Cowper send for his Horse from your house the next day?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: I can't say that, I was not in the way.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did he come to your House afterwards?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: No I am sure he did not.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was the Horse in your Stable when it was sent for?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: And he did not come to your House again, before he went out of Town?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Do you know which way he went out of Town?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.p: Hatsell. Did Mr Cowper use to lodge at your house at the Assizes?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: No my Lord, not since I came there, the Sessions before he did.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Where did you come to invite me to dinner?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: At Mr Barefoot's.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Then you knew I was to lodge there?

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.p: Hatsell. Who wrote the Letter on Friday, that Mr Cowper would lodge there?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: I know not who wrote it, his Wife sent it.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did he tell you he would lodge there that night before he went away?

sp.speaker: VValker.
sp.p: When he went from Dinner he said so.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p:
Call Iames Berry (who was sworn) Now, my Lord, we will give
Evidence of the manner, how she was found. Mr Berry do you remember when Mrs Stout was found by your Mill?

sp.speaker: Perry.
sp.p: No indeed I do not know just what day it was.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: When you found her, do you remember how▪ in what manner she was found?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes, I went out in the morning to shoot a flash of water by 6 a Clock, and. I saw something a floating in the water, so I went out to see what it was, and I saw part of her Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see her Face?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No, not then.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was her face under water, or above?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No part of her body was above water, only some part of her Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How many foot deep might the water be?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: 5 foot deep.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: And how much was she under water, do you conceive?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: She might be under water about 5 or 6 inches.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Then her whole body was not under water, was it?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was her face under water?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Did she lye upon her face, or her back?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: She lay upon her side.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: When she was taken out were her eyes open or shut?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Her eyes were open.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was she swell'd with water?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: I did not perceive her swell'd; I was amaz'd at it, and did not so much mind it as I should.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: But you remember her eyes were staring open?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see any marks or bruises about her?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you see her legs?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr.Cowper.
sp.p: They were not above water?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Could you see them under water?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: I did not so much mind it.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did she lye straight or double, driven together by the stream?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: I did not observe.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you not observe weeds and trumpery under her?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: There was no weeds at that time thereabouts?

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was the water clear?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No, it was thick water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was there any thing under her in the water, to prevent her sinking?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No, I do not know there was, she lay on her right side, and her right arm was driven between the stakes, which are within a foot of one another.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did any thing hinder her from sinking?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Not that I saw▪

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you help to take her out from the stakes?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Iohn Venables.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Mr Berry, if I understand you right, you say her right arm was driven between the stakes, and her head between the stakes, could you perceive her right arm, and where was her left arm?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Within a small matter upon the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.p: Hatsell. Did you see her head and arm between the stakes?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes, her arm by one stake, and her head by another.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did the arm hang down, or how?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: I did not mind so much as I might have done?

div.p: Then Iohn Venables was sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see Mrs Stout, when she was taken out of the water, and as she lay in it?

sp.speaker: Venables.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Give an account how you found her.

sp.speaker: Venables.
sp.p: She was floating upon the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How? was all her body, or what part in the water?

sp.speaker: Venables.
sp.p: She lay upon her right side, and this arm upon the water, rather above the water, her ruffles were above the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you help to take her out?

sp.speaker: Venables.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Were her eyes open then?

sp.speaker: Venables.
sp.p: Her eyes were open when I saw her, but I did not see her when she was t •… ken out.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did any thing hinder her from sinking?

sp.speaker: Venables.
sp.p: I saw nothing to hinder her if she would have sunk.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Leonard Dell (who was sworn) Did you see this Mrs Stout in the Water?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Pray tell us in what posture she was found.

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: I saw her floating in the River, I saw her Face and her Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Were her Cloaths all above the water,

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Her Stays and her Coat that she had next her.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Were these plainly above the water?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Some part of them.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see her face, was that above the Water?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: No Sir, it was between the Piles, she lay on her right side, and her head was beween the stakes, and her right arm.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you help to take her out of the water?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Yes▪

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did any thing hinder her from sinking?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Neither stakes nor any thing there.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did her arms or neck stick to the stakes?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Not to my thinking.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was the water clear, or weedy.

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: It was very clear.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How many foot deep was it?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: I know not, but it might be 5 foot deep.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you help to take her out of the water?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and we took her and carried her into the meadow just by, and laid her on the bank.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you observe her face, neck or arms to be bruis'd?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: I saw no bruise at all.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: How did you know but her right arm did reach to the ground, since you did not see it?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: We could see her arm lye in this manner between the Piles, the right arm was downwards, for she lay on one side.

sp.speaker: Iury-man.
sp.p: Did you see any arm above in the water?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: You should propose your questions to the Court.

sp.speaker: Iury man.
sp.p: My Lord, I desire to know where was her left arm.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Where was her left arm?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: I can't tell how it did lye, I did not observe it.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: When you took her out of the water did you observe her body swell'd?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: We carried her into the meadow, and laid her on the bank side, and there she lay about an hour, and then was order'd to be carried into the Miller's.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Did you observe that any water was in her body?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: None at all that I could see, but there was some small matter of froth came from her mouth and nostrils.

sp.speaker: Iury-man.
sp.p: My Lord, I desire to know whether her Stayes were lac'd?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Yes she was laced.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: If I take you right, you say she was strait lac'd.

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Her Stayes were lac'd.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: And you say there was froth and foam came out of her mouth and nostrils?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Pray what quantity?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: I could hold it all in the palm of my hand.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: How was she taken out of the water?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: My Lord, we stood upon the Bridge, I and another man, where she lay, and he laid hold of her, and took her out.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: And did you not perceive she was hung?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray where was she laid when she was taken out?

sp.speaker: Dell
sp.p: In the place call'd the Hoppers just by.

sp.speaker: Mr▪ Cowper.
sp.p: How long did she lye there?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: About an hour.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you stay there all that time?

sp.speaker: Dell.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: And did the froth continue to issue from her mouth and nostrils?

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: He told you, Mr Cowper, he could hold it all on the palm of his hand.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Iohn Ulfe. (who was sworn) Iohn Ulfe, did you see Mrs Stout when she was taken out of the water?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Give an account of the condition she was in.

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: She lay on one side, I help'd to take her out.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did she hang or stick by any thing?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: There was nothing at all to hold her up; she lay between a couple of stakes, but the stakes could not hold her up.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see her after she was taken out?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did any water come out of her?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: Nothing at all, only a little froth came out of her nostrils.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call▪ Kath. Dew. (who was sworn.) Did you see Mrs Stout taken out of the River?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see her in the River before?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How did she lye in the River?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: She lay side way with her Eyes open, and her Teeth clenched in her hea •… , with water flowing a little from her face, some part of her and her Petticoats w •… e above water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did nothing hold her from sinking?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: Her right arm lay against the stake.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see her after she was taken out of the River?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was she swell'd?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: I did not perceive she was swell'd at all.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones
sp.p: Did you handle he?

sp.speaker: Dw▪
sp.p: No I toucht nothing but her Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you observe her Legs were in the water?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: No I did 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you see where her right arm was?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: I could not see her right arm, the water flow'd over it.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you see her after this time?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: No Sir, I saw her taken out, but not afterward.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Did you see her after she lay on the ground?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: How was she then?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: She purged at the Nose and one of her Eyes, I did not take particular notice after she was out, the notice I took was when she was in the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: What did you see at her Eye?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: Froth, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones
sp.p: Did you see her after she was stripp'd naked?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: No my Lord▪

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was it a settled frothing, or a purging?

sp.speaker: Dew
sp.p: A purging froth.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Did any body wipe it off?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I did not see any body do it.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Then there was no new froth come?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: No my Lord, I saw her froth at the Nose and one of the Eyes, as soon as she was taken out, but I did not stay long.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Was she in her Stayes?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Was she not laced?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: Yes she was lac'd before and behind.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Thomas Dew (who was sworn) Did you see this Mrs Stout in the water? Pray give my Lord and the Jury an account what posture she was in.

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: I saw her lying in the water floating, above the water I will not say, but the water ran some small matter over her, her right arm was wi •… hin the stake, and her left arm without, she lay just upon her side, and I saw her when she was first taken up and her Shoes and Stockings were as clean as when they were put on, no mud nor dirt upon them, and I saw her Shoes and her Stockings, as high as her knee almost▪ but I saw no dirt.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Do you believe that she had been sunk to the bottom?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: She di •… not look as if she had▪ nor I see no water come from her.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you observe, that she was swelled at all?

sp.speaker: Dew.
sp.p: No, nor swell'd that I perceiv▪d abit, there was a little froth that came out of her Nose, and about her (I can't say from her •… ye) in that it was a small quantity.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones
sp.p: Call Mr Edward Blackno. (who was sworn) Did you see Mrs Stout, when she lay in the water?

sp.speaker: Blackno.
sp.p: Yes I did see her lye in the water floating, I was so near, that I saw the Millers man lift her up by one of her arms out of the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was the arm bent or straight?

sp.speaker: Blackno.
sp.p: It hung in this manner (showing the Court how with his own arm.)

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: The other Witnesses said, she lay on her right side.

sp.speaker: Blackno.
sp.p: Yes she lay on her right side, and her arm in this manner.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Did you observe her to be swelled?

sp.speaker: Blackno.
sp.p: I did not see her taken out.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Did you observe any thing to hinder her from sinking?

sp.speaker: Blackno.
sp.p: No I did not, nothing but the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: I think Sir, if I heard you right, you say, that this taking by the arm and stirring her, was before she was taken out of the water, then I would know after she was stirred was she let go again, was you by at the taking of her up?

sp.speaker: Blackno.
sp.p: No I was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bar Hatsell.
sp.p: He told you she was floating when he saw her, and that nothing hindered her from sinking.

div.p: Then William Edmunds and William Page were sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Edmunds did you see Mrs Stout when she was in the water?

sp.speaker: Edmunds.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Give an account what posture she was in?

sp.speaker: Edmunds.
sp.p: She lay against the stake, her heah lay against the stake in the River, we were coming up in a Barge, and called to a Miller to draw the water, but he said he could not, for then she would swim through, and then we came on, and see her lye in the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did any thing hinder her from sinking?

sp.speaker: Edmunds.
sp.p: Not that I see.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did no part of her legs or arms stick? did you see her taken out?

sp.speaker: Edmunds.
sp.p: No I did not, I was gone, I did not know whether they would take her out or no.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Page, did you see Mrs Stout upon the water?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Tell us how she lay.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: She lay floating in the water on her right side, with her head between the stakes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did her Arms or Cloaths, or any thing stick?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Not that I saw.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did any thing hinder her from sinking?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I saw nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you see her legs or knees?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No I could not, they were not out of the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Swear Srs Ann Ulfe (which was done) Did you see Mrs Stout in the water?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: Yes I help'd to pull her out, she lay on one side in the water floating, and the water came over her face.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did she stick by any thing?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: One of her arms was about the post.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: It got through the grate.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: But it did not hang.

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you take her out?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you mind her Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: Yes I turn'd up her petticoat in the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Had she Gloves on?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How were her Shoes and Stockings?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: They were not muddy, her Stockings were rowl'd down, she had no Garters on.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: You say, one arm lay through the stakes, where lay the other?

sp.speaker: Ulfe.
sp.p: The other was down in the water. (William How was sworn.)

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see Mrs Stout in the water?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I see her lye upon the water, she lay afloat▪ she might lye 3 or 4 inches deep in the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did any of her Cloaths lye above the water?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Some part of her Coats lay above the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did any thing hinder her from sinking?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I saw nothing, I saw them take her out, and did not perceive she hung any way, she lay with one arm, and her head in the grate, but I did not perceive she hung.

div.p: Iohn Meager sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Well, do you give an account of what you know of Mrs Stout being in the water?

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.p: I see Mrs Sarah Stout floating in the water, her right arm in the grate, and her left arm with the stream.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did she hang or stick by any thing?

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.p: No, neither hang nor stick, she floated.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you see some body go through the Blue-coat building about 11 a clock?

sp.speaker: Meager.
sp.p: No Sir, I was abed before 9.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, we will give an account how she was when she was stript, and they came to view the body. Call Iohn Dimsdale, junior. (who was sworn.)

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: My Lord, I was sent for at night on Tuesday the last Assizes—

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordship pleases, I have some Physicians of note and eminency that are come down from Londón, I desire they may be call'd into Court to hear what these Surgeons say.

sp.speaker: Mr▪ Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: Ay, by all means.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord, there is Dr▪ Sloane, Dr Garth, Dr Morley, Dr Gilstrop, Dr Harriot, Dr Wollaston, Dr Crell, Mr William Cowper, Mr Bartlett, and Mr Camlin.
(Who respectively appear'd in Court.)

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Give an account how you found Mrs Stout.

sp.speaker: Mr Baron Hatsell.
sp.p: You are a Physician, I suppose, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: A Surgeon, my Lord. When I was sent for to Mrs Stout's, I was sent for two or three times before I would go; for I was unwilling after I heard Mrs Stout was drown'd; for I thought with my self, what need could there be of me when the person was dead; but she still sent; and then I went with Mr Camlin, and found a little swelling on the side of her neck, and she was black on both sides, and more particularly on the left side, and between her Breasts up towards the Collar-bone, that was all I saw at that time, only a little mark upon one of her arms, and I think upon her left arm.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How were her Ears?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: There was a settling of blood on both sides the neck, that was all I saw at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How did you think she came by it?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: Truly I only gave an account just as I say now to the Gentlemen at that time, I saw no more of it at that time, but about six weeks after the Body was opened by Dr Phillips—

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord, he is going to another piece of Evidence, and I would ask him—

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Let us have done first; how was her Ears?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: There was a blackness on both ears, a settling of blood.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Sarah Kimpson.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Mr Cowper, now you may ask him any thing, they have done with him.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: I would ask him whether he was not employed to view these particular spots he mentions at the Coroners Inquest.

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: I was desired to look upon the face and arms, and breast, because they said there was a settling of blood there.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: When you returned to the Coroners Inquest, what did you certify as your opinion?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: I did certify there was a settling of blood, but how it came I could not t

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: I ask you, Sir, did not you say it was no more than a common stagnation usual in dead bodies?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: I do not remember a word of it.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Sir, I would ask you, you say the spot was about the Collar-bone▪ was it above or below?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: From the Collar-bone downwards.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Had she any Circle about her neck?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: No, not upon my oath.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Swear Saraeh Kimpson. Did you observe this Mrs Sarah Stout when she was stript how her body was?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Pray give an account of it.

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: She had a great settlement of blood behind her left ear, as much as my hand will cover, and more, and she had a settlement of blood under her Collar-bone.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see nothing about her neck?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Nothing round her neck; on the side of her neck there was a mark.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was there any other part bruised.

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Only her left wrist, and her body was very flat and lank.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray what day was it that you saw her?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: It was the day she was found.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Was she not laced?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: She was laced.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you help to strip her?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iones.
sp.p: Did her body seem to be swell'd, or was there any water come from her?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: I did not observe the least drop of water that appeared any way.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Do you know what did purge from her?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Nothing that I saw.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones
sp.p: Had not you a Child drowned there lately?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Yes, about ten weeks ago.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: And you found her?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: She was drowned at night, and we found her next morning.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Where did you find her, at the top or at the bottom of the water

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: At the bottom.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: How was she?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: She was swell'd as much as she could hold.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Were her eyes shut or open?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Her eyes were shut, and the Child was laced as tight as the Coat could be.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was the Child opened?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: And what was in the body of the Child?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: 'Twas very full of water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Sarah Peppercorn.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: You say you viewed the Child, had it any settlement of blood?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: I saw none.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: And you viewed the body?

sp.speaker: Kimpson.
sp.p: Yes. (Then Sarah Peppercorn was sworn.)

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you see the body of Mrs Sarah Stout after it was stript and laid out?

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: I did Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: In what condition did you find her?

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: I did not see her till she was brought home to her Mothers, and there was a rumour in the Town, that she was with Child, and I was sent for to give an account whether she were or •… o, and I found she was not, and I help'd to pull off her Cloaths, and she was very clear as any I ever knew, only had a black place on the side of her head, and in another place about her ear, but how it came I know not.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you observe how her body was?

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: Her body was very well as any Womans could be.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did your observe any water, or any such thing come from her?

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was there any purging at her mouth ornost

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: A little froth, as any body might have.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: At what hour did you see her?

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: I believe it might be 9 or 10 a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: In the morning▪

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but I can't give a just account of the time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: What was you sent for?

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: To know if she was with Child; for it was reported she had drowned her self because she was with Child, and so her mother desired me to come to give an account that it was not so, and I found that it was not so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: You are a Midwife, are you not?

sp.speaker: Peppercorn.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, Then Eliz. Husler was sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Had you the view of the body of Mrs Sarah Stout the day you heard she was drowned?

sp.speaker: Husler.
sp.p: She was not drowned, my Lord, I went thither and helped to pull off her cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: In what condition washer body?

sp.speaker: Husler.
sp.p: Her body was very lank and thin, and no water appeared to be in it.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: VVas there any water about her mouth and nose?

sp.speaker: Husler.
sp.p: Not when I saw her.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you mind her about her neck and head?

sp.speaker: Husler.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, there was a settling of blood at the top of the Collar bone, just here, and there was a settling of blood upon both her ears, most about her left ear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iones.
sp.p: Swear Ann Pilkinton, (which was done.) Did you see the body of Mrs Stout after she was drowned?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Pray in what condition was she when she was stript?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: I was in the house when she was brought in dead, and old Mrs Stout desired me to help to lay her out, and taking a view of her, I did not at all perceive her body to be swelled.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: VVas there any water came our upon the moving of it?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: No, I did not perceive any; and by a further view, I saw a redness on the left side of her head, and her ear was black, and there was a little mark upon her breast on the left side.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: VVhat colour was it of?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: It seem'd reddish and blackish, as to colour it was like a settling of blood; I can't tell how to make it out very well.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Had she any circle round about her neck?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: No, not that I see.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray did not you make some deposition to that purpose, that you know of?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: Sir, I never did, and dare not do it.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: It was read against me in the Kings▪ Bench, and I will prove it, was not Mr Meade with you at the time of your examination?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did not he put in some words, and what were they?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: But you never swore so, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: No, I don't believe I did, if I did it was ignorantly.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Here is her examination, it is cross her neck.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Was Mr Young of Hertford, the Constable, present when you were examined?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: Yes he was so. The next day Mrs Stout sent for me again, to put on be Daughters Shrowd, and I was one that helped to draw the sheet away, and there was no •… one drop of water come from her, and I laid a cloath under her Chin▪ when I help'd her into the Coffin, but I did see the least moisture come from her.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: What day was it, that you put her into the Coffin?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: The next day after she was dead.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Do you know nothing of her being convey'd into the Barn?

sp.speaker: Pilkington.
sp.p: I hapned to be in the B •… rn, Mrs Stout desired me to go with her, and she was brought up in an indecent manner, and I put a sheet about her. I was in Mrs Stout's house before her daughter was brought thither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iones.
sp.p: Call Dr Coatsworth, Dr Nailer, Dr Woodhouse, Dr Bid •… .

div.p: Mr Coatsworth was sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Pray▪ Doctor, had you a view of the body of Mrs Stout?

sp.speaker: Coatsworth.
sp.p: Yes, I had, Sir, I am a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Pray give an account of it, and what your opinion was how she came by her death.

sp.speaker: Coatsworth.
sp.p:
My Lord, in April last I was sent for by Dr Philips, to come to Hartford to see the body of Mrs Stout opened, who had been 6 weeks buried, and he told me that there was a suspicion she was murthered, and that her Relations were willing to have her taken up and opened. I came down, I think on the 27th of April, and lay at Mrs Stout's house that night, and by her discourse I understood she wanted to be satisfied, whether her Daughter was with Child. I told her it was my opinion we should find the parts contained in the Abdomen so rotten, that it would be impossible to discover the Uterus from the other parts; however, if she would have her opened▪ I could not discover whether she was with Child unless the Infant was become boney. Her face and neck to her shoulders appeared black and so much corrupted, that we wore unwilling to proceed any further; but however her mother would have it done, and so we did open her, and as soone as she was opened we perceived the Stomach and Guts were as full of wind, as if they had been blown with a pair of Bellows▪ we put her Guts aside, and came to the Uterus, and Dr Philips shewed it us in his hand, and afterwards cut it out and laid it on the Table, and opened it, and we saw into the cavity of it, and if there had been any thing there as minute as a hair, we might have seen it, but it was perfectly free and empty; and after that he
put the Intestines into their places, and we bid him open the Stomach, and it was opened with an Incision Knife, and it sunk flat, and let out wind, but no water; afterwards we opened the Breast and Lobes of the Lungs, and there was no water; then we look'd on each side, and took up the Lobes of the Lungs too, to see if there was no Water in the Diaphragm, and there was none, but all dry. Then I remember, I said this woman could not be drowned, for if she had taken in water, the water must have rotted all the Guts; that was the construction I made of it then, but for any marks about her head and neck, it was impossible for us to discover it because they were so rotten.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: You say, this inspection was made about six weeks after she was dead?

sp.speaker: Coatsworth.
sp.p: It was made on the 28th of April.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: She was drowned on the 13th of March.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iones.
sp.p: Did you make an incision into those parts of the neck and head.

sp.speaker: Coatsworth.
sp.p: No, I told Mrs Stout and her Son, if you imagine the Skull to be injur'd▪ I will open the Head, for if the scalp be never so rotten, yet if the Skull has suffered any impression I shall discover it, they said, they did not suspect a broken Skull in the case, and so we did not examine it.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: But all the other parts were sound?

sp.speaker: Coatsworth.
sp.p: Yes sound to a miracle, for I did not imagine we could find them so.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Iohn Dimsdale.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: My Lord, I would know, and I desire to be heard to this point; I think where the Coroners Inquest have view'd the body, and the relations have been heard, and the Body buried, that it is not to be stirr'd afterwards for any private inspection of parties, that intend to make themselves Prosecutors, but if it is to be taken up, it is to be done by some legal authority, for if it should be otherwise▪ any Gentleman may be easily trepann •… , for instance, if they should have thought fit after the Coroners View to have broken the Skull into a hundred pieces. This was a private view altogether among themselves, certainly if they intended to have prosecuted me, or any other Gentleman upon this Evidence, they ought to have given us notice, that we might have had some Surgeons amongst them, to super intend their proceedings. My Lord, with submission▪ this ought not to be given in Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Mr Cowper I think you are not in earnest, there is no colour for this objection, if they did take up the body without notice, why should not that be Evidence, unless you think they had a design to forswear themselves.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Had you a Melius Inquirendum, or any lawful wartant for making this inspection?

sp.speaker: Coatsworth.
sp.p: No there was not.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.p: Hatsell. Suppose they did an ill thing in taking up the body without some order, though I don't know any more ill in taking up that body than any other; but however, is that any reason why we should not hear this evidence.

sp.speaker: Coatsworth.
sp.p: Mr Camblin, Sir William Cowpers Surgeon was thereby.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Mr Dimsdale Senior. (who was sworn) Had you a view of the body after it was taken up?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr▪ Iones.
sp.p: Pray▪ give your opinion of it?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: On the 28th of April▪ as I remember, I was sent for down by Mrs Stout, to view the body of her Daughter. Her Daughter was just taken out of the Ground but not opened, they had just toucht the body, but not opened the Skin when I came there—

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Are you a Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p:
Yes, my Lord. Finding her head so much mortified down to her neck, we thought all the parts were seized, and had a consultation whether we should open her or not, but Mrs Stout was very much enraged▪ because a great
scandal had been raised, that her Daughter was with Child, and she said, she would have her opened to clear her reputation; with that we opened her, and found her body as found as any Flesh could be, no manner of putrifaction in her Lungs or any other part, but she was very full of Wind. We searched the Stomach and the Thorax, and found not one drop of water about it, I was more curious than the rest, and turn'd away her Legs, to see if the Coffin was soil'd, and the Coffin and Shrowd were not wet. Her Uterus was taken out, and I saw no manner of sign of Conception. After this we had a consultation to consider, whether she was drown'd or not drowned, and we were all of Opinion that she was not drowned, only Mr Camlin desired he might he excused from giving his opinion, whether she was drowned or not, but all the rest of us did give our opinions, that she was not drown'd.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Give your reasons, why you believ'd she was not drown'd.

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: My reason was this, beccuse we found no water in her, her intestines were not putrified, for if there had been water in her, that would have caused a fermentation, and that would have rotted the Lungs and Guts.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Could you tell so many weeks after whether she was drowned or no?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, for this reason, for if she had been drowned, there had been some sign of water▪ and if there had been a pint of water it would have rotted her Lights and her Guts, and that is done in a weeks time by fermentation.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Sir I desire to know, whether according to reason and your skill after six weeks time, it's possible, there should be water in the Thornx.

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: I do believe there may be some, for it can't come out after the body is dead, but by putrifaction, and there was no putrifaction, but it was firm and sound.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: What parts would have been putrified by the water?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: The Lungs and Bowels.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: And they were firm?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: They were, and if there had been water, they would have been putrified.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Call Iohn Dimsdale, Junior.

sp.speaker: Iuryman.
sp.p: Was her Navel started?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Sen.
sp.p: No I never saw such a body body in my Life.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you ever see a body that was drowned opened 6 weeks after?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Sen.
sp.p: No never. If a body be drown'd a fortnight, the bowels will be so rotten, there will be no coming near it, and I took particular notice, and I did not see one drop of water.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Was the Coffin close?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Sen.
sp.p: Yes it was close and dry as any board whatsoever, and all the parts sound, but the head and neck, and left arm.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: What do you think could be the reason of that?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Sen.
sp.p: The left arm was rottener than the other, the neck was rotten before.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: What did you take to be the cause of it?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Sen.
sp.p: I can't judge of that.

div.p: Call Iohn Dimsdale, Junior. (who was sworn.)

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Jun.
sp.p: My Lord, the body was opened before I came to see it, and they were drawing up an Affidavit, that there was no water in the body, and they desired me to sign it, but I desired first to look into the body, and I did look into it, and turn'd the Intestines aside, and there was no water in it, but the head from the neck was very much putrified.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Do you believe she was drown'd?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Jun.
sp.p: No, I believe not.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you open the Child that was drowned? What difference was there between the body of that Child and this?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Jun.
sp.p: The Child was extreamly swell'd in the Belly and Stomach, and had abundance of water in it.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was the Child lac'd that you opened?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Jun.
sp.p: It was laid upon the Table before I came.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: How long was it before the Child was opened?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Jun.
sp.p: It was drowned in the afternoon, and opened the next morning.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: You said, Sir, you was ask'd to sign the Affidavit before you saw the body, and you were honest, and would see the body first, pray who askt you?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Jun.
sp.p: All of them did.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Who in particular, if you please name them?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale Jun.
sp.p: Mr Coatsworth, Mr Philips, Mr Camlin, &c. they asked me to set my hand to it, because they thought I had seen it before.

div.p: Then Dr Dimsdale was sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Mr Robert Dimsdale was you at the opening of this body?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: I came after it was opened, my Brother and I came together.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: What profession are you of, a Physician?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: Yes, when the body was taken up, they desired us to be there, to inspect the body, but before we came it hapned they had opened the body, and were setting their hands to a Paper, a sort of Affidavit, and when I came in, they would have had us set our hands, but we would not, till we had look'd upon the body, and went and laid it open again, and we did not find the least drop of water neither in the Thorax nor Abdomen.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper▪
sp.p: Is it possible there should be water in the Thorax, according to your skill?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: Yes we did think there would have been, if she had been drown'd.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: Could you expect to find it, so long as six weeks after.

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: We should have expected that or a putrifaction, but we found no putrifaction, neither in the Bowels nor Intestines, but only upon her Head and Shoulders, and one Arm.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray by what passage does the water go into the Thorax.

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: 'Twill be very difficult for me to describe the manner here, but we should have found some in the Stomach and Intestines.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray Sir, how should it go into the Thorax?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: By the Lymphaduct, if carried by any means.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: When the party is dead, can any water pass into any part of the body?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: We opened the Abdomen of the Child that was drowned, and found in the several cavities abundance of water.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: When a person is dead can they receive any water after?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: No, for all the parts are clos'd and contracted.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray if a dead body be put into the water, will not the water come into the Windpipe?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: I question whether it will or no.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Was her mouth shut?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: She was putrified about the head and shoulders and one arm, that I saw was putrified, it was the left arm as I take it.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: What is your opinion as to her death?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: I believe if she had been drowned, there would have been a putrifaction of the Abdomen first, and it was her extream parts, her arm, her head and her breast, that was putrified, but her Bowels seem'd firm and sound.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Then you don't think her death was by drowning?

sp.speaker: Dimsdale.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray did not you give some Certificate or Paper, declaring the death of this Gentlewoman, before you saw the body at all?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: No I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Sir, I would ask you, was not you angry, that Mr Camlin would not join with you in opinion?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Pray did not you tell him, that you were agraduate Physician, and was angry he would not join with you?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: Suppose I did.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell.
sp.p: But did you do so or no?

sp.speaker: Dr Dimsdale.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, we had some words about it.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Swear Dr Coatsworth. (which was done) Now, my Lord, we call these Gentlemen that are Doctors of skill, to know thèir opinion of them, that are found floating without water in them, how they come by their death.

sp.speaker: Dr Coatsworth.
sp.p: I have not seen many drowned bodies to make observation upon, but it is my opinion, that every body that is drowned is suffocated by water passing down the Wind▪ pipe into the Lungs upon inspiration, and at the same time, the water pressing upon the Gullet, there will be a necessity of swallowing a great part of it into the Stomach: I have been in danger of being drowned my self, and I was forced to swallow a great quantity of water. If a person was drowned and taken out immediately, as soon as the suffocation was effected, I should not wonder, if there were but little water in the Stomach and Guts, but if it lay in the water several hours, it must be very strange if the belly should not be full of water, but I will not say, it is impossible it should be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: I desire to know whether this Gentleman attempted to drown himself, or was in danger of being drowning by accident.

sp.speaker: Dr Coatsworth.
sp.p: It was by accident, I was passing up the Ship side, and took hold of a loose Rope instead of the entring Rope which failing me I fell into the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: But you struggled to save yourself from drowning?

sp.speaker: Dr Coatsworth.
sp.p: I did so, I have seen several persons that have been drowned, and they have lain several days, until by a fermentation, they have been rais▪d, but. I never made my observations of any persons, that have been drowned above six hours.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: Did you ever hear of any persons that as soon as they were drowned had swam above water.

sp.speaker: Dr Coatsworth
sp.p: I have not known such a Case.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
sp.p: Did you ever know, Sir, a body that was otherwise killed to float upon the water?

sp.speaker: Dr Coatsworth.
sp.p: I never made any Observation of that.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar. Hatsell▪
sp.p: Dr Brown has a learned discourse in his Vulgar Errors upon this subject, conceining the floating of dead bodies, I don't understand it my self, but he hath a whole Chapter about it.

div.p: Then Dr Nailor was sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr Iones.
sp.p: We ask you the same question that Dr Coatsworth was asked, what is your opinion of dead bodies, if a body be drowned will it have water in it or not.

sp.speaker: Dr Nailor.
sp.p: My Lord, I am of opinion, that it will have a quantity if it be drowned, but if there be no water in the body, I believe that the person was dead before it was put into the water.

sp.speaker: Mr Cowper.
